block.p: Weeks
This
On
Week
List
Fiction
WE'LL MEET AGAIN, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Pocket, $7.99.) A woman tries to free herself of the suspicion that she murdered her husband.
CARNAL INNOCENCE, by Nora Roberts. (Bantam, $7.50.) A concert violinist visiting Innocence, Miss., becomes enamored of a man suspected of being a serial killer.
WHERE THE HEART IS, by Billie Letts. (Warner, $12.) A pregnant teen-ager finds help and caring in a small Oklahoma town.
BLACK FRIDAY, by James Patterson. (Warner Vision, $6.99.) A secret militia lays siege to New York City.
FORTUNE'S HAND, by Belva Plain. (Dell, $7.99.) A young attorney's ideals are tested when he joins a prominent law firm.
TOM CLANCY'S NET FORCE: Night Moves, created by Tom Clancy and Steve Pieczenik. (Berkley, $7.99.) Computer terrorism in 2011.
THE TESTAMENT, by John Grisham. (Island, $7.99.) A billionaire, a lawyer and a missionary are brought together by a startling secret.
JOINING, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $7.50.) In 1214, an Englishwoman changes her feelings about her partner in an arranged marriage.
ON MYSTIC LAKE, by Kristin Hannah. (Ballantine, $6.99.) A woman who has been betrayed by her husband is reunited with her first love.
HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling. (Scholastic, $5.99.) A British boy attends a school for witchcraft.
*WORST FEARS REALIZED, by Stuart Woods. (HarperPaperbacks, $7.50.) A police officer turned lawyer seeks a serial killer he once knew.
THE BLUEST EYE, by Toni Morrison. (Plume, $12.95.) The story of an 11-year-old black girl -- pregnant by her father -- who prays for blue eyes.
A NEW SONG, by Jan Karon. (Penguin, $12.95.) A clergyman and his wife move 600 miles, creating new friendships and maintaining old ones.
THE DEVIL'S TEARDROP, by Jeffery Deaver. (Pocket Star, $7.99.) On Dec. 31, 1999, a scheme involving a robotic assassin threatens Washington.
*HUSH MONEY, by Robert B. Parker. (Berkley, $7.50.) The private eye Spenser encounters racial, sexual and academic politics when a black professor is implicated in a suicide.
Weeks
This
On
Week
List
Nonfiction
THE SEAT OF THE SOUL, by Gary Zukav. (Fireside/S&S, $12.) How daily activities can be enhanced by feelings of meaning and purpose. (+)
GIRL, INTERRUPTED, by Susanna Kaysen. (Vintage, $12.) A memoir of a young woman's mental illness.
A CHILD CALLED ''IT,'' by Dave Pelzer. (Health Communications, $9.95.) The autobiography of a man who survived his mother's abuse. (+)
THE ELEGANT UNIVERSE, by Brian Greene. (Vintage, $15.) A presentation of superstring theory, which attempts to mediate between quantum mechanics and general relativity.
*ANGELA'S ASHES, by Frank McCourt. (Touchstone/S&S, $14 and $7.99.) An Irish-American writer recalls his childhood in Limerick.
BELLA TUSCANY, by Frances Mayes. (Broadway, $15.) An American remembers a spring and summer spent in the romantic sections of Italy.
*SPONTANEOUS HEALING, by Andrew Weil. (Fawcett, $12.95; Ballantine, $7.99.) How the body heals itself. (+)
THE LOST BOY, by Dave Pelzer. (Health Communications, $10.95.) The author of ''A Child Called 'It' ''recalls his life in foster homes. (+)
*THE PERFECT STORM, by Sebastian Junger. (HarperPerennial, $14; HarperPaperbacks, $6.99.) The story of the northeaster of 1991.
*TRAVELING MERCIES, by Anne Lamott. (Anchor, $13.) A chronicle of the author's journey toward faith and spirituality.
*THE ONION'S FINEST NEWS REPORTING, edited by Scott Dikkers and Robert Siegel. (Three Rivers, $16.) A collection of humor pieces.
THE PROFESSOR AND THE MADMAN, by Simon Winchester. (HarperPerennial, $13.) How a murderer and certified lunatic helped James Murray compile the Oxford English Dictionary.
*THE MILLIONAIRE NEXT DOOR, by Thomas J. Stanley and William D. Danko. (Pocket, $14.) An analysis of the lives of wealthy Americans. (+)
*REACHING TO HEAVEN, by James Van Praagh. (Signet, $7.50.) A ''renowned medium'' discusses death, the spirit world and reincarnation.
*GUNS, GERMS, AND STEEL, by Jared Diamond. (Norton, $14.95.) A physiologist attributes Western dominance to geography. (+)
Weeks
This
On
Week
List
Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous
CHICKEN SOUP FOR THE TEENAGE SOUL III, compiled by Jack Canfield, Mark Victor Hansen and Kimberly Kirberger. (Health Communications, $12.95.) Inspirational stories. (+)
RICH DAD, POOR DAD, by Robert T. Kiyosaki with Sharon L. Lechter. (Warner, $15.95.) Teaching one's children how to get rich and stay rich.
DR. ATKINS' NEW DIET REVOLUTION, by Robert C. Atkins. (Avon, $14 and $6.99.) A physician recommends ways to lose weight and achieve a healthy body. (+)
ORGANIZING FROM THE INSIDE OUT, by Julie Morgenstern. (Owl/Holt, $14.) How to organize your home, your office and your life.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending April 29, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 60,000 other retailers, statistically weighted to represent all such outlets. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+)indicates that some stores received bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/books.
